facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated May 30, 1964 of the Central Government Labour Court, Dhanbad in Application No. L.P. 123 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated May 30, 1964 of the Central Government Labour Court, Dhanbad in Application No. L.P. 123 of 1962. R. Gokhale, C. A.

facts.text: Central Labour Court, Dhanbad rejected application under s. 33(2)(b) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 on May 13, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, by the appellant Bank, is directed against the order, dated May 13, 1964, of the Central Labour Court, Dhanbad, rejecting an applic

facts.text: Respondent was Assistant Accountant at the main Office of the Bank at Calcutta at the material time.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was, at the material time, the Assistant Accountant, at the main Office of the Bank, at Calcutta. In view of certain serious irregularities, noti

facts.text: Bank noticed serious irregularities in respondent's work in Current Accounts Department, particularly current account ledgers Nos. 4 and 6.

anchor.surface_text: In view of certain serious irregularities, noticed by the Bank, in respect of the work of the respondent in the Current Accounts Department and, in particula

facts.text: Respondent suspended with immediate effect by order dated March 8, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: r, in current account ledgers Nos. 4 and 6, by order dated March 8, 1961, the respondent was suspended, with immediate effect. He was also informed that the

facts.text: Charges against respondent communicated by communication dated March 13/14, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: He was also informed that the charges against him would be communicated, in due course. By a further communication, dated March 13/14, 1961, the respondent

facts.text: Main allegations: overdrafts allowed by respondent in ledger accounts Nos. 4 and 6 without sanction of competent authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The main allegations were that, in respect of ledger accounts Nos. 4 and 6, standing in the names of Messrs. Commercial Bureau and Messers Evergreen Paper

facts.text: Other allegations: respondent did not bring irregularities to notice of authorities and pass-book of ledger No. 4 was missing.

anchor.surface_text: The other allegations were to the effect that the respondent, who was charged with the duty of supervising both these ledgers. did not bring to the notice.

facts.text: Respondent admitted in reply dated March 17, 1961 granting overdrafts temporarily without reference to higher authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent sent a reply, dated March 17, 1961, wherein he has admitted that, in the course of discharge of his routine duties and responsibilities, i

facts.text: Respondent stated no financial loss to Bank due to overdrafts.

anchor.surface_text: He also stated that the Bank had not been put to any financial loss because of his having granted the overdrafts but, he again admitted his negligence,

facts.text: Charge-sheet communicated on June 3, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Bank was not satisfied with the explanation offered by the respondent, and communicated a charge-sheet, on June 3, 1961.

facts.text: Enquiry to be held by Agent of the Bank on June 20, 1961 at 3.30 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: The Bank also informed the respondent that he would, be given a further opportunity to explain his conduct, in relation to those matters, and defend hi

facts.text: Respondent in reply dated July 11, 1961 again admitted allowing overdrafts without reference to higher authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent again sent a reply, dated July 11, 1961, to the charge-sheet served on him. In this reply also, he admitted that, in the course of discha

facts.text: In enquiry, respondent admitted committing blunder in granting advances of about Rs. 87,000 without reference to Agent.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, no doubt, appears to have stated that some of the cheques, issued to the parties concerned, have been initialled by an Officer of the B

facts.text: Respondent did not want to cross-examine anybody in enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: the latter was asked as to whether he wanted to examine, or cross-examine those persons and the respondent very clearly stated that he did not like to

facts.text: Management examined Mr. Bhatena and Mr. Savkar in presence of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The Management then examined Mr. Bhatena and Mr. Savkar, two Officers of the Bank, in the presence of the respondent.

facts.text: Enquiry Officer report dated November 10, 1961 found respondent guilty of main charges and recommended discharge.

anchor.surface_text: The Enquiry Officer, in his report, dated November 10, 1961, has, after referring to the nature of the enquiry conducted by him, found the respondent g

facts.text: Respondent exonerated of minor allegations by Enquiry Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the other minor allegations, that the respondent caused other officers to record debit balances incorrectly, and the loss of the pass book

facts.text: Bank discharged respondent by letter dated June 27, 1962 with pay-order for Rs. 472.70 for July 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Bank communicated the order of discharge, by its letter, dated June 27, 1962, enclosing a pay-order for Rs. 472.70 being the wages for one month,

facts.text: Respondent filed representation dated July 11, 1962 to Managing Director admitting fault.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, who had a right to file an appeal, against this order of discharge, based upon the finding of the Enquiry Officer, does not appear to

facts.text: Managing Director rejected representation on September 17, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Managing Director, by his communication, dated September 17, 1962, rejected the representation made by the respondent, and declined to reinstate

facts.text: Bank filed application under s.33(2) before National Industrial Tribunal on March 17, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile, inasmuch as an industrial dispute was pending before the National Industrial Tribunal, the appellant had filed, an application, befor

facts.text: Application transferred to Central Government Labour Court, Dhanbad on April 18, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: This application was transferred to the Central Government Labour Court, Dhanbad, on April 18, 1962.

facts.text: Respondent in objections dated September 2, 1963 claimed overdrafts due to oral orders and no opportunity to cross-examine or union representation.

anchor.surface_text: in the objections, dated September 2, 1963, filed by the respondent before the Labour Court, for the first time he raised the plea that in view of the

facts.text: Labour Court held domestic enquiry not fair, violating natural justice, declined approval.

facts.text: Supreme Court held enquiry fair, no violation of natural justice, set aside Labour Court order.

facts.text: Respondent served Bank for over 20 years without blemish.

anchor.surface_text: Finally he made a plea that he had been serving the institution for over 20 years without any blemish,

facts.text: No cheque initialled by Mr. Bhatena traced during enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court, by its order under attack. has held that the domestic enquiry, conducted by the Bank, as against the respondent, is not fair and that

There can be no controversy that the principles of natural justice must be observed, in the conduct of a domestic enquiry, and the workman, concerned, must be allowed reasonable opportunity to defend himself. It has also been held, by this Court, that rules of natural justice require that the workman, proceeded against, should be informed clearly of the charges levelled against him witnesses should be formally examined in the presence of the employee, in respect of the charges if statements, taken previously and given by witnesses, are relied on, they should be made available to the workman concerned the workman should be given a fair opportunity to examine witnesses, including himself in support of his defence and the Enquiry Officer should record his findings, based upon the evidence so adduced.

concepts.interpretation: In domestic enquiries: clear charges, formal witness exam in presence, prior statements supplied, opportunity to examine/cross-examine/adduce evidence, findings on evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that no such conclusion could be drawn from the decision, referred to above. In that case... Malak Ram, at all stages, stoutly denied...

holdings.text: There has been no violation of the rules of natural justice in the domestic enquiry conducted by the Bank against the respondent.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent admitted guilt at all stages including replies and enquiry; opportunities to cross-examine witnesses given and declined; distinguished from cases where denial occurred; examining workman first allows explanation when admission present.

holdings.text: The Bank complied with the proviso to s.33(2)(b) of the Industrial Disputes Act as interpreted by this Court.

anchor.surface_text: At this stage, it may be mentioned that the Labour Court has held in favour of the management, that it has complied with the proviso to s. 33 2  b  of the Act, as interpreted, by this Court, in its decision in Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Gobind 1 . That is, it has held that the action of the Bank, by way of discharge, payment of wages and making of the application for approval, have been taken as part of the same transaction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Labour Court held in favour of management following Strawboard Manufacturing Co.; action, payment of wages, and application part of same transaction.

holdings.text: The findings of the Labour Court that the respondent was not permitted to cross-examine witnesses and was prejudiced without Union assistance are erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: So far as grounds Nos. 2 and 3, given by the Labour Court are concerned, it is clear from the record of the enquiry proceedings, that the respondent was permitted to put questions to Mr Bhatena and Mr. Savkar, who were examined, during the enquiry  1  1962 Supp. 3 S.C.R. 618. We have also referred to the fact that the Enquiry Officer has recorded that the respondent has stated that he has nofurther questions to be put to them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Record shows respondent put questions to witnesses Bhatena and Savkar and stated no further questions; declined to cross-examine others; no request for Union representation made at any stage including before Labour Court.

holdings.text: Examining the respondent first in the enquiry does not violate natural justice where he admits guilt.

anchor.surface_text: Then the question is as to whether the inquiry proceedings can be considered to have been conducted in violation of the rules of natural justice, inasmuch as the respondent was examined, even in the first instance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished Associated Cement Co. where workman denied charges; here consistent admissions make management evidence an empty formality; examination allowed explanation and mitigation.

holdings.text: The order of the Labour Court refusing approval under s.33(2)(b) is erroneous and is set aside; approval is granted.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it follows that the order of the Labour Court, refusing to grant approval, as asked for, by the management, is erroneous and, as such, it is set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Domestic enquiry fair and natural justice not violated; proviso complied with.

holdings.text: If workman admits guilt, insisting on management evidence first is empty formality; management may examine workman first for explanation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Admission obviates need for formal proof; allows mitigation; still opportunity to cross-examine subsequent witnesses.

holdings.text: Principles of natural justice in domestic enquiries require clear charges, witnesses formally examined in presence, prior statements supplied, opportunity to cross-examine and adduce evidence, findings based on evidence.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no controversy that the principles of natural justice must be observed, in the conduct of a domestic enquiry, and the workman, concerned, must be allowed reasonable opportunity to defend himself. It has also been held, by this Court, that rules of natural justice require that the workman, proceeded against, should be informed clearly of the charges levelled against him witnesses should be formally examined in the presence of the employee, in respect of the charges if statements, taken previously and given by witnesses, are relied on, they should be made available to the workman concerned the workman should be given a fair opportunity to examine witnesses, including himself in support of his defence and the Enquiry Officer should record his findings, based upon the evidence so adduced.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restatement of settled law from prior decisions of this Court.

anchor.surface_text: Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Gobind 1 . That is, it has held that the action of the Bank, by way of discharge, payment of wages and making of the application for approval, have been taken as part of the same transaction.

precedents.cited_proposition: interpretation of proviso to s. 33(2)(b) of the Industrial Disputes Act such that discharge, payment of wages, and application for approval form part of the same transaction

anchor.surface_text: Associated Cement Co. Ltd., v. Workmen 1  viz. It seems to us that it is number fair in domestic enquiries against industrial employees that at the very companymencement of the enquiry, the employee should be  1  1964 3 S.C.R. 652, 661. closely cross-examined, even before any other evidence is led against him. and draws the inference that under numbercircumstances should a workman, whose companyduct is the subject of disciplinary proceedings, by a domestic tribunal, should be examined, in the first instance.

precedents.case_name: Associated Cement Co. Ltd. v. Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: principles of natural justice violated if employee is closely cross-examined at commencement of domestic enquiry before other evidence
precedents.cited_holding: It seems to us that it is number fair in domestic enquiries against industrial employees that at the very companymencement of the enquiry, the employee should be closely cross-examined, even before any other evidence is led against him.

anchor.surface_text: At this stage, it may be mentioned that the Labour Court has held in favour of the management, that it has complied with the proviso to s. 33 2  b  of the Act, as interpreted, by this Court, in its decision in Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Gobind 1 . That is, it has held that the action of the Bank, by way of discharge, payment of wages and making of the application for approval, have been taken as part of the same transaction.
Therefore, it follows that the order of the Labour Court, refusing to grant approval, as asked for, by the management, is erroneous and, as such, it is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: So far as grounds Nos. 2 and 3, given by the Labour Court are concerned, it is clear from the record of the enquiry proceedings, that the respondent was permitted to put questions to Mr Bhatena and Mr. Savkar, who were examined, during the enquiry  1  1962 Supp. 3 S.C.R. 618. We have also referred to the fact that the Enquiry Officer has recorded that the respondent has stated that he has nofurther questions to be put to them.
Therefore, it follows that the order of the Labour Court, refusing to grant approval, as asked for, by the management, is erroneous and, as such, it is set aside.
